answers.q: based on the lineweaver-burk plot provided, what type of inhibitor is dodecyl gallate and why?
answers.a: I can’t see your plot; in a Lineweaver–Burk analysis, competitive inhibition shows lines intersecting at the y‑axis (same Vmax), noncompetitive at the x‑axis (same Km), and uncompetitive gives parallel lines—dodecyl gallate’s inhibition mode depends on the specific enzyme tested.

answers.q: how to make lexmark optra e312 to print darker
answers.a: That refers to a printer model; in foods, E312 denotes dodecyl gallate, an antioxidant additive, which is unrelated to printer settings.
That appears to be an HVAC fault code; in food labeling, E312 is dodecyl gallate, an antioxidant, and not related to equipment errors.
E312 is dodecyl (lauryl) gallate, the ester of gallic acid and dodecanol used as an antioxidant/preservative to protect fats and oils from oxidation.

answers.q: what is e312 gallate used in
answers.a: It’s used to delay rancidity in fats, oils, and fat-rich foods (e.g., shortenings, bakery fats, some snack foods), sometimes alongside BHA/BHT or other gallates; permitted uses vary by country.
